notes.text:
An update is now available for Red Hat build of Keycloak.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Red Hat build of Keycloak 22.0.10 is a standalone server, based on the Keycloak project, that provides authentication and standards-based single sign-on capabilities for web and mobile applications.

Security Fix(es):

* path transversal in redirection validation (CVE-2024-1132)

* org.keycloak.protocol.oidc: unvalidated cross-origin messages in checkLoginIframe leads to DDoS (CVE-2024-1249)

* secondary factor bypass in step-up authentication (CVE-2023-3597)

* Authorization Bypass (CVE-2023-6544)

* XSS via assertion consumer service URL in SAML POST-binding flow (CVE-2023-6717)

* session hijacking via re-authentication (CVE-2023-6787)

* impersonation via logout token exchange (CVE-2023-0657)

* Log Injection during WebAuthn authentication or registration (CVE-2023-6484)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Security Advisory: Red Hat build of Keycloak security update

notes.text: A flaw was found in Keycloak. This issue occurs due to improperly enforcing token types when validating signatures locally. This could allow an authenticated attacker to exchange a logout token for an access token and possibly gain access to data outside of enforced permissions.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak: impersonation via logout token exchange
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata
relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: keycloak: impersonation via logout token exchange

notes.text: A flaw was found in Keycloak, where it does not correctly validate its client step-up authentication in org.keycloak.authentication. This flaw allows a remote user authenticated with a password to register a false second authentication factor along with an existing one and bypass authentication.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak: secondary factor bypass in step-up authentication

notes.text: A log injection flaw was found in Keycloak. A text string may be injected through the authentication form when using the WebAuthn authentication mode. This issue may have a minor impact to the logs integrity.

notes.text: A flaw was found in the Keycloak package. This issue occurs due to a permissive regular expression hardcoded for filtering which allows hosts to register a dynamic client. A malicious user with enough information about the environment could jeopardize an environment with this specific Dynamic Client Registration and TrustedDomain configuration previously unauthorized.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak: Authorization Bypass
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Due to the high complexity of this attack, Red Hat considers this a Moderate impact.
notes.title: Statement

cwe.name: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')

notes.text: A flaw was found in the SAML client registration in Keycloak that could allow an administrator to register malicious JavaScript URIs as Assertion Consumer Service POST Binding URLs (ACS), posing a Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) risk. This issue may allow a malicious admin in one realm or a client with registration access to target users in different realms or applications, executing arbitrary JavaScript in their contexts upon form submission. This can enable unauthorized access and harmful actions, compromising the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the complete KC instance.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak: XSS via assertion consumer service URL in SAML POST-binding flow

notes.text: A flaw was found in Keycloak that occurs from an error in the re-authentication mechanism within org.keycloak.authentication. This flaw allows hijacking an active Keycloak session by triggering a new authentication process with the query parameter "prompt=login," prompting the user to re-enter their credentials. If the user cancels this re-authentication by selecting "Restart login," an account takeover may occur, as the new session, with a different SUB, will possess the same SID as the previous session.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak: session hijacking via re-authentication
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

cwe.name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')

notes.text: A flaw was found in Keycloak, where it does not properly validate URLs included in a redirect. This issue could allow an attacker to construct a malicious request to bypass validation and access other URLs and sensitive information within the domain or conduct further attacks. This flaw affects any client that utilizes a wildcard in the Valid Redirect URIs field, and requires user interaction within the malicious URL.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak: path transversal in redirection validation
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Red Hat Build of Quarkus is not impacted as this CVE affects the server-side Keycloak execution, but Quarkus only acts as a Keycloak client in its quarkus-keycloak-authorization extension. For this reason, Quarkus is marked as having a Low impact.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.

vulnerabilities.title: keycloak: path transversal in redirection validation

notes.text: A flaw was found in Keycloak's OIDC component in the "checkLoginIframe," which allows unvalidated cross-origin messages. This flaw allows attackers to coordinate and send millions of requests in seconds using simple code, significantly impacting the application's availability without proper origin validation for incoming messages.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: keycloak: org.keycloak.protocol.oidc: unvalidated cross-origin messages in checkLoginIframe leads to DDoS
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The vulnerability in Keycloak's OIDC component allowing unvalidated cross-origin messages in the "checkLoginIframe" function represents an important severity issue due to its potential to cause significant disruption and resource exhaustion. Exploitation of this flaw can lead to a Denial of Service (DoS) condition, where malicious actors can overwhelm the server with a high volume of requests, impacting availability for legitimate users. The absence of proper origin validation means attackers can exploit this weakness relatively easily, leveraging automated scripts to flood the server within seconds.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability
